Award.AwardTitle: ATD: Collaborative Research: Statistical Ensembles for the Identification of Bacterial Genomes
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research focuses on reducing bioterrorism threat by integrating tools from genomics and statistics in ways that have not been previously examined. The investigators develop novel statistical theory and computational tools for accurate pathogen detection based on next generation sequencing data. Key research directions involve (i) classification by sequence enrichment; (ii) comparison of empirical clusterings and reference genomes; and (iii) shrinkage estimation and model selection in hierarchical log-linear models. In addition to an in-depth characterization of the theoretical properties of these new statistical inference techniques, the investigators perform a thorough assessment of their practical importance in the context of the detection and identification of bacterial genomes. This assessment is done using publicly available data from sources such as the Human Microbiome Project, the NCBI Short Read Archive, the European Bioinformatics Institute, and the Broad Institute. The applicability of this new methodology is broad and relates to high-dimensional settings in which choosing an appropriate class of candidate statistical models is difficult. The investigators study statistical ensembles, combinations of techniques that have been shown to provide more reliable inferences than any single statistical approach. As opposed to existing work which combines models from the same class, this new framework concerns ensembles that cross class boundaries and optimally combine inferences from multiple models from several model classes. These ensembles are expected to have distinct advantages over existing approaches, such as robustness to model misspecification and improved predictive performance.

The new statistical methodology developed in this proposal has the potential to substantially improve the response of federal and international agencies to a bioterrorism attack through a rapid identification of differences in microbial genomes and their accurate classification as harmless or potentially pathogenic. The impact of these algorithms for pathogen detection on both information technology and civil infrastructure is maximized through their implementation in user-friendly, open-source computational tools and software that will be freely available to the public. The project also has a significant educational and mentorship component for students and postdoctoral fellows who are interested in enhancing our ability to respond rapidly and appropriately to (i) incidents of bioterrorism, and (ii) microbial threats to public health.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project was to develop and provide reliable statistical tools for the detection and identification of bacterial genomes from
data obtained from complex microbial communities. Towards this goal we conducted research on novel methods for classification, clustering, and model selection, and examined the properties and performance of these methods for this specific application. These examinations were done using data from several microbial and ecological studies involving human, wastewater, and viral samples.

We developed new approaches to the assessment of cluster stability, the detection of microbial genomes in complex ecological samples, the identification of interactions between microbes in such samples, the clustering of bacterial genomes in low or high dimensions. This work has generated four published manuscripts and four additional manuscripts in review for publication, plus two open source software packages with example data. Our research also generated two poster presentations and numerous oral presentations at national and international conferences.

The findings, results, and associated techniques developed under this award represent statistically sound approaches to the analysis of both bacterial genomes and/or metagenomic data from microbial ecosystems. This is a significant contribution to the base of knowledge in statistical metagenomics. In addition, our techniques represent novel tools for metagenomic data analysis, and as such are relevant to other scientific disciplines such as bioinformatics, microbiology, and microbial ecology. These tools can be used to analyze metagenomic data from any type of microbial ecosystem, e.g., soil, rhizosome, human, rumen, and/or marine. Hence the techniques have the potential to impact many scientific disciplines where microbial systems play a role in biological phenomena.

During the course of this project we collaborated with faculty and research staff at the University of Washington, the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, the University of Miami, and the University of North Carolina-Charlotte. We were involved in the training of 3 students and 1 postdoctoral researcher who have received their graduate degrees or have obtained faculty positions. One additional student is currently pursuing his doctoral degree in Computer and Information Sciences, and is continuing the research supported by this award.

As a result of this award we have used our technique to analyze data from diabetic foot ulcers and help identify biomarkers of wound healing as a step toward the development of novel microbial therapeutic agents. We are also developing a collaboration to use our methods in forensic science to identify biomarkers of postmortum interval to improve determination of time of death.
